author: sky.cactus
content: <@387536747476549632> commit a hash of a thing in one bl,ck, then wait a while, then reveal what you previously committed.  The hash is unique to you, and the front runner doesn't know the answer, and they cannot do the action without revealing in advance.

author: zkfloof
content: <@!301186049323958275> seems like a beautiful solution. how come contracts haven't implemented this? Is it because contract needing to hash data is gas costly?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@387536747476549632> requires multiple transactions separated by time.  Poor UX for regular users.

author: zkfloof
content: are there any EIPS proposed around this?

author: sky.cactus
content: No need for an EIP.  ENS uses this strategy to prevent front-running of name purchases.

author: sky.cactus
content: You commit a hash of the name you want, then wait a couple minutes, then execute the purchase of the name.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thee name isn't revealed to the network until the second transaction, and by then it is too late for a front-runner to steal the name from you.
